name: Vitamin B7 (Biotin)
summary: Vitamin B7, commonly known as biotin, is a water-soluble B-complex vitamin that supports fatty acid synthesis, glucose metabolism, and amino acid breakdown. It is often marketed for hair, skin, and nail health.
description: Biotin is an essential coenzyme for carboxylase enzymes involved in critical metabolic pathways, including fatty acid synthesis, gluconeogenesis, and branched-chain amino acid metabolism. Although true biotin deficiency is rare, it can cause symptoms such as hair loss, brittle nails, dermatitis, neurological disturbances, and developmental delays in infants. Biotin supplementation is commonly marketed for cosmetic benefits such as hair and nail strength, although clinical evidence for these effects in healthy individuals is limited. High-dose biotin may interfere with certain laboratory tests, including thyroid function and troponin assays.

metadata.natural_source: Egg yolk, nuts, seeds, legumes, whole grains, organ meats

primary_indications: Prevention and treatment of biotin deficiency
monitoring_required: Awareness of lab test interference with high-dose use

items: Treatment and prevention of biotin deficiency
Support for hair and nail strength (limited evidence)

sections.text: Biotin acts as a coenzyme for carboxylases, facilitating reactions in fatty acid synthesis, gluconeogenesis, and amino acid catabolism. It is essential for maintaining energy metabolism and normal cellular function.

adult.clinical: 5–10 mg/day for biotinidase deficiency; up to 5 mg/day used for hair/nail health

sections.pediatric: 5–20 mcg/day depending on age; higher doses for metabolic disorders

sections.text: Deficiency symptoms improve within weeks of supplementation; cosmetic effects (if any) may take months.

serious: Interference with laboratory assays leading to false results

other: High-dose biotin can interfere with lab tests, including thyroid function, hormone levels, and troponin assays.
Use caution in patients undergoing diagnostic testing.

items: Consider lab interference if abnormal test results occur

sections.pregnancy: Safe at dietary intake levels; higher doses should be supervised
sections.pediatrics: Safe at recommended intakes; therapeutic doses used for biotinidase deficiency

sections.text: Not required; supplementation may be stopped without tapering.

items: Biotin deficiency is rare but may occur in long-term raw egg white consumption due to avidin binding biotin.
High-dose biotin is sometimes marketed for beauty benefits, though clinical evidence is weak.
Important to notify clinicians about biotin use before laboratory testing.
